core_claim: Male seahorses, not females, become pregnant and give birth to live young—sometimes over 1,000 at a time.

supporting_details.reproductive process: Female deposits eggs into male's brood pouch, where he fertilizes and incubates them
supporting_details.locations: Worldwide in shallow tropical and temperate waters
supporting_details.notable study: Wilson et al., Journal of Fish Biology, 2001

source_citation: Wilson, A. B., Ahnesjö, I., Vincent, A. C. J., & Meyer, A. (2001). The dynamics of male pregnancy in seahorses and pipefishes. Journal of Fish Biology, 58(4), 1049–1065.
why_strange: In most species, females carry offspring—male pregnancy is extremely rare in the animal kingdom

core_claim: The lyrebird can mimic almost any sound it hears—including chainsaws, camera shutters, and car alarms—with astonishing accuracy.

supporting_details.recorded mimicry: Chainsaws, camera clicks, dogs barking, human voices
supporting_details.notable documentation: David Attenborough's BBC series 'The Life of Birds' (1998)
supporting_details.vocal range: More than 20 different species and artificial sounds

source_citation: Attenborough, D. (1998). The Life of Birds. BBC; Also: Dalziell, A. H., & Magrath, R. D. (2012). 'Superb lyrebirds mimic complex sounds during sexual display'. Current Biology, 22(6), R231–R232.
why_strange: It's bizarre that a bird can imitate man-made mechanical sounds indistinguishable from the real thing

core_claim: The horned lizard can squirt blood from its eyes as a defense mechanism against predators.

supporting_details.defense method: Ruptures tiny blood vessels around its eyes to shoot a stream of blood up to 5 feet
supporting_details.purpose: Deters predators, especially canines, due to foul taste
supporting_details.location: Southwestern United States and northern Mexico
supporting_details.first documented: 19th century naturalists; detailed in Schmidt & Davis, 1941

source_citation: Schmidt, K. P., & Davis, D. D. (1941). Field Book of Snakes of the United States and Canada. G.P. Putnam's Sons.
why_strange: Few animals weaponize their own blood, especially by shooting it from their eyes
